This section contains interactive worksheets that we will work through during class to get a bit of practice working with R before turning to using R on your own computer within [RStudio](https://posit.co/products/open-source/rstudio). These worksheets provide a sort of coding playground that you can always come back to if you want some practice. Note that more complex worksheets may take a moment for the everything to load.

An interactive code section looks like this. Make changes in the text box and use the blue `Run Code` button to run the code. The output, if any, will be printed below the code. Change the code and run it as many times as you want. The original text can be reset with the `Start Over` button.


```{webr} 
2 + 3
```

The interactive code may not always be complete in which case you will be prompted to complete the code to get it to run correctly. These interactive code blocks may have hints and even solutions.

For example, fill in the blank so that the result of the sum is 10.

```{webr}
#| exercise: ex_1
1 + 2 + 3 + ______
```

::: { .hint exercise="ex_1" }
::: { .callout-note collapse="false" }
## Hint

Make sure to delete the underscores before entering the correct number.

```r
1 + 2 + 3 + 
````

:::
:::

::: { .solution exercise="ex_1" }
::: { .callout-tip collapse="false" }
## Solution
You can copy the code in the solution by mousing over the far right side of the solution code.

```r
1 + 2 + 3 + 4
````

:::
:::

We will be able to practice quite complex skills with these interactive lessons, including data visualizations. Let's see how this works using the `penguins` dataset that comes with newer versions of R. The dataset contains body measurements of three species of penguins collected by the [Palmer Station](https://pallter.marine.rutgers.edu) in Antarctica. For more about the data, see the [palmerpenguins package](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/).

![Artwork by @allison_horst](../files/img/lter_penguins.png "Title: The Palmer Penguins"){width=50% fig-alt="A cartoon-style drawing of chinstrap, gentoo and ad√©lie penguins."}

For instance, we can visualize a comparison of the flipper length to the body weight of the three species of penguins. Try it out by running the code! Test out what happens if you change things.[^1]

```{webr} 
ggplot(data = penguins, 
       aes(x = flipper_len,
           y = body_mass)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species, shape = species),
             size = 3, alpha = 0.8, na.rm = TRUE) + 
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkorange", "purple", "cyan4")) +
  labs(title = "Penguin size, Palmer Station LTER",
       x = "Flipper length (mm)",
       y = "Body mass (g)",
       color = "Penguin species",
       shape = "Penguin species") + 
  theme_minimal()
```

The ability to run R code in your browser is relatively new and is made possible by the [quarto-live extension](https://r-wasm.github.io/quarto-live/).

[^1]: This visualization follows that from the [palmerpenguins package](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/index.html) documentation. The only difference is that this visualization uses the data that now comes with R from version 4.5.
